history.content:
CS 200 and 300 courses do not count. CS 200 courses may be petitioned to the EECS dept (you would see your ESS advisor, Bryan Jones, to pick up a petition) to count towards the 45 engineering units but will mean you won't be able to have it double count should you choose to attend graduate school. 

Your 45 units will be composed of the following:

- 20 units of Lower-Division EECS (EE 20, EE40, CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C)

- 20 units of Upper-Division EECS (5 upper-division EECS)

- 5 units additional engineering units (can be more upper-division EECS or courses in an engineering department).

(*Refer to Footnote 4: http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/academic-departments-programs/electrical-engineering-computer-sciences)

Keep in mind that CS 70 is not part of your 45 engineering units and that DeCals and self-paced courses (e.g. CS 9 series) also do not count.

Hope this helps. 

Olivia (ESS advisor)

Keep in mind that CS 70 is not part of your 45 engineering units and that DeCals and self-paced courses (e.g. CS 9 series) also do not count.

Hope this helps. 

Olivia
Does CS 375 count as one of the engineering courses required in the 45 units
history.subject: CS 375
